head.title: Cougars and Lawyers Win in California Ballot Measures

hedline.hl1: Cougars and Lawyers Win in California Ballot Measures

block.p: While Senator Bob Dole's victory in Tuesday's California primary was a predictable political yawn, considerably less predictable was voters' wholesale rejection of three ballot propositions that, if passed, would have put California in the forefront of the much-disputed national movement to reduce court litigation.

The defeat of the measures, in the face of a sharp-edged and expensive advertising campaign that painted lawyers as greedy shysters, was another demonstration of the political resilience and resourcefulness of the trial lawyer lobby.

While Senator Bob Dole's victory in Tuesday's California primary was a predictable political yawn, considerably less predictable was voters' wholesale rejection of three ballot propositions that, if passed, would have put California in the forefront of the much-disputed national movement to reduce court litigation.

The defeat of the measures, in the face of a sharp-edged and expensive advertising campaign that painted lawyers as greedy shysters, was another demonstration of the political resilience and resourcefulness of the trial lawyer lobby.
And it was an even more impressive defense, coming in a state that is one of the most litigious in the nation, home to some of the nation's priciest and most flamboyant lawyers.

Notable, too, on Tuesday were several other voter decisions -- on whether to protect mountain lions, whether to open future primaries to all voters regardless of party affiliation, and whether to grant a second term to District Attorney Gil Garcetti, Los Angeles County's chief trial lawyer and the chief strategist of the unsuccessful prosecution of O. J. Simpson.
The mountain lions won. The next primaries will be "open." And Mr. Garcetti failed to win 50 percent of the vote and now faces a fall run-off against one of his deputies.

The three litigation propositions, designed to curtail both the frequency and cost of suits, were pushed aggressively by state and national corporations and political conservatives. They were opposed adamantly by state and national trial lawyers and consumer organizations, including Ralph Nader's group.

Especially at issue were the increasing number of suits that involve automobile insurers, companies whose stock often fluctuates and individuals whose lawyers' fees are contingent on the outcome of suits.

Proponents of the three measures argued that the first would reduce insurance premiums because it called for the adoption of the "no fault" form of restitution, with hardly any suits permitted, no matter which driver might be at fault.

The second measure, its backers said, would encourage business activity in California, especially formation of risky but often highly profitable high-technology companies, because it would require anyone suing a company over the performance of its stock to pay the cost of the company's defense should the company prevail in the suit.

And the third measure, proponents said, would reduce the burden of legal costs on companies and individuals because it would encourage out-of-court settlements, with lawyers' fees capped at 15 percent rather than the usual 30 or 40 percent.

Opponents of the measures, including Mr. Nader, who flew to the state several times from Washington to lobby against them, argued that they were "lawyer bashing" and designed to deny consumers their traditional right to sue.
The first two measures were defeated by margins of roughly 3 to 2. But the third measure lost by only a couple of points.

Seeming undeterred by Tuesday's defeats, proponents of tort reform are talking about trying to put their measures back on the ballot in November for a second round of voting, hardly an unexpected move in a state where ballot propositions are a favorite political tool for settling disputes.

"They'd be fools to try," said Bill Carrick, a Democratic political consultant who helped direct the opposing forces. "It's obvious that California voters and consumers are tired of being trampled by big business interests."
But Ken Khachigian, a Republican consultant on the other side of the dispute, saw the Tuesday defeat in a more optimistic light.
"We've been around on this stuff before and this time the vote showed us doing better," he said. "We're closing the gap."

Whatever the merits of the arguments on either side of the issue, the sharp edge of the debate and the money spent by each camp to make its point was a good measure of the intensity that infuses the tort reform movement, under way in the country now for two decades, off and on, with neither side yet showing any sign of prevailing, either at the state level or at the Congressional level in Washington.

In all, proponents and opponents of the California tort propositions spent more than $25 million on television and other types of advertising to promote and defeat the three measures, with each side accusing the other of greed and duplicity about its goals.
That was a large media "buy" even by the political standards of the nation's most populous state. Further, significant amounts of the money came from out of state.

In the other significant votes on Tuesday, a proposal to make future Golden State primaries more competitive by opening them to all voters was solidly approved, doing away with the current "closed" system that permits only Democrats to vote in Democratic primaries, only Republicans to vote in Republican primaries, and so forth.
Both Democratic and Republican leaders in the state opposed the proposition as "meddling." Its supporters argued that open voting would result in more moderate, more electable nominees.
As for the mountain lion proposal, which called for lifting a 24-year ban on sport hunting of cougars, it was easily defeated.

Cougars are relatively rare California creatures. But now and again, as suburban development encroaches on their territory, they tangle with humans. Over the past two years, at least two people have been fatally mauled.
The Garcetti vote?

Facing sharp criticism of his office by five challengers, he mounted a $1 million advertising campaign and managed to come in first -- but with a 38 percent plurality rather than the required simple majority.
In the fall he will face the second-place finisher, John Lynch, one of his deputies.
